subject: Re: [junit] testCreate, testUpdate, testDelete: make one   single test out of it?
msgSnippet: ... Typically the more tests there are that depends on the particular state of a database, the more difficult it is to execute those tests when you need to.
messageBody:
>That what I'm trying to understand. What is the mythical problem that
>would get
>me into trouble? Or is it just some design guideline or best practice that
>we
>should follow when it make sense?

Typically the more tests there are that depends on the particular state of a database, the more difficult it is to execute those tests when you need to.

Also, consider the case where you create a certain simple set of test data to satisfy the needs of today's tests. You put that test data into the database and execute your tests. Everything is fine. Tomorrow, you write a test that requires additional data. You add the additional data to satisfy the new tests *and* change the expected results for some of the old tests, so you need to change the old tests. If you do this often enough, it will drive you nuts.

>I indeed put the persistence tests into a separate suite. It is not mean
>to run
>everytime it compiles. People need to know it write into the database and
>thus
>need to have it properly setup. The create() method itself is fairly
>straight
>forward. It's just a few setString() and executeQuery(). I don't know if it
>worth the effort to mock the infrastructure to test these few statements
>really
>got executed. The most interesting part for me is to see the queries got
>executed correctly and the fields do match the schema.

The most interesting part for me is to see the query string is correctly generated. I don't generally feel the need to test that the database vendor correctly implements the JDBC standard. As long as I can generate the SQL query correctly and can make business objects from a ResultSet, the rest is up to the database vendor, and their code probably works. If it doesn't, then we'll find out soon enough.
